items.title: Wood Chip
items.description: How much wood could wood chip chuck? Nanocellulose, a wood-derived material, has been shown as a viable option to replace silicon as a substrate for computer chips.

items.title: Silk Chip
items.description: Stronger than steel, light as air; silk can do it all. Silk works like glass fiber optic cables to transmit laser light on an integrated circuit chip.

items.title: Algae Chip
items.description: Not edible, but pretty cool anyway. Algae has potential to be harnessed for directing and storing electrical current.

items.title: Plant Sensor
items.description: A plant, as a sensor! Plants have vast potential to act as information systems through their innate and accurate sensing and communication networks.

items.title: Algae Battery
items.description: Batteries, but make it green. Algae has the potential to be used as bio-batteries. It works similarly to solar cells by capturing sunlight, stores it, and converting it to electric current.

items.title: Mycelium Computing
items.description: Fungus is cool, duh. The network of fine filaments provide for a rife ground to imagine computing circuits using fungus structures.

items.title: Slime Circuit
items.description: Slime mold has been shown to be able to be incorporated into computer circuitry. They are able to act as ‘memristors’ - that is, resistors that are able to ‘remember’ specific charges even after electric flow is turned off, allowing for more efficient computer memory.

items.title: DNA Data Storage
items.description: Human hard drives, anyone? The 'code' of DNA can be used to store bits of data, and its highly stable and space efficiency makes it a viable storage alternative.

items.title: Bamboo Keyboard
items.description: Tough, sturdy, and light. Bamboo's versatile nature and durability make it perfect for hard-hitting fingers.
